mxCell.value: Does temperature influence the rate of cellular respiration?
Objective: I will be measuring the rate of oxygen consumption of pea plants using respirometers and heat variance to determine whether temperature has any affect on cellular respiration.

Procedure: 1. First, determine the mass of the three trials of peas. Record your measurements. Obtain the equivalent mass of non-living material (colored balls) to use in the control chambers. It is important to label the control and experimental chambers to avoid confusion. 2. Set up 3 baths using the backing pans. Each bath should be 3 cm deep. • Bath 1 - ice water (use thermometer to measure and record temperature) • Bath 2 - room temperature • Bath 3 - 40 C hot water 2. Obtain 6 vial (chambers) and 6 respirometer tops (stopper-and-pipet assemblies). These should already be assembled for you. 3. Place one absorbent cotton ball in the bottom of each vial. Insert the dropper into the bottom of the vial and add about 40 drops of KOH solution. 4. Place the plastic screen (separators) into each vial (chamber). 5. Place the peas into 3 of the chambers; these will be the experimental chambers. Firmly insert the stopper into the end of the vials. To prevent leaks, you may want to use some BioFilm. 6. Place the small colored balls (of equivalent mass) into the 3 control chambers. 7. Place the sealed chambers into the baths. One control and one experimental into each bath. Let the chambers acclimate for 5 minutes. 8. Add monometer fluid and when fluid passes 0 cm mark, begin recording. This will be time 0. Record the fluid moving down the pipet and the temperature every 5 minutes for 30 minutes. Try to maintain the temperature of each bath as constant as possible.

Materials: Nongerminating Fast Plants seeds or seeds of several species of plants (presoak in water night before) Safety goggles or glasses, aprons, and gloves 6 glass chambers 6 stoppers with holes 6 small black screens (seperators) BioFilm Thin-stem plastic dropping pipettes 6 40 µL glass capillary tubes nonabsorbent cotton Ice (1 kg) 3 low-lipped rectangular backing pans (~50 cm x 30 cm) 3 Constant-temperature water baths - room temp, ice bath (4C), and hot water bath (40C) 3 Celsius thermometers, centimeter rulers, permanent glass-marking pens Manometer fluid (soapy water with red food coloring) 15% solution of KOH, potassium hydroxide solution (or NaOH, Drano)
Hypothesis: I predict that peas exposed to a higher temperature will consume more oxygen than those under lower temperature.
